description: An intriguing industrial heritage site hiding in plain sight. A fascinating complex of Grade II listed buildings, unseen since the 1950s. Set to be renovated into the Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration by Tim Ronalds Architects.

events.name: New River Head Guided tour
events.notes: The buildings at New River Head have lain unused since the 1950s and the condition of the site reflects this. There is dust and some uneven ground inside, cobbled paving leading up to the buildings and currently there is no lift access to upper level floors. Accessibility  The buildings at New River Head have lain unused since the 1950s and the condition of the site reflects this.     Please be aware that this site currently has:  - cobbled paving leading up to the buildings  - dust, steps and uneven ground inside the buildings  - no lift access to upper level floors  - limited places to rest - most of the tour will be spent moving around the site  - two portaloos, one of which is accessible     We recommend:  - wearing sturdy shoes  - dressing for the weather - much of the tour is outside  - wearing a face mask in dusty spaces     We understand visitors may have a range of access needs. Please email us on info@houseofillustration.org.uk if you have any questions or queries.     Covid-19  Site tours take place outdoors and in large, well-ventilated spaces. Tour groups are limited to six guests and two members of staff. When indoors, please wear a face covering and maintain 2m distance from people who are not part of your household.  Please do not attend if you have any symptoms of Covid-19, including a temperature or persistent cough.

factsheet.heading: New River Head - Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration
paragraphs: Wandering around the heart of Clerkenwell in central London, you may well glimpse an intriguing complex of buildings hiding in plain sight between Roseberry Avenue and Amwell Street.

This is New River Head, a site with a history of civil engineering innovation dating from the 17th century; a time when London’s rapidly growing population called for a new approach to the supply of water.

From 1609-1613 the New River was made; an aqueduct cut by 200 labourers to enable fresh water from springs in Hertfordshire to flow to a reservoir at New River Head. From there it was distributed to paying customers in the City via overground wooden pipes.

As demand for water in west London grew at the beginning of the 18th century, pumping technology was needed to increase the pressure of the water and enable it to travel beyond the City. The buildings that exist at New River Head today were built to house these changing technologies. 
At first, a six-sail windmill was used to pump water from the site, but after it was badly damaged by a storm in 1720, the building was converted into a horse gin. Today, the base of the windmill remains, and is the oldest construction of its kind in central London.

In 1768, the site’s first engine house, designed by John Smeaton, was constructed. Extensions were made to accommodate bigger engines in 1786 and 1795, designed by architect and engineer Robert Mylne. A boiler house and coal store were added in 1848, designed by William Chadwell Mylne to service his father’s engine house. All these structures stand today, however with the installation of electric power on the site in the 1950s, the engines were removed and the building’s iconic chimney was demolished.

Now, after decades lying derelict, House of Illustration has acquired the site and plans to renovate and reopen it in 2023 as the Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration; a cultural and architectural landmark with galleries, learning spaces, landscaped gardens, a café and shop.

Turning a derelict heritage site into a new public space is not without its challenges. An architectural competition at the start of 2019 led to the appointment of Tim Ronalds Architects, whose previous projects include Wilton’s Music Hall and Hackney Empire. The practice’s approach of opening up important heritage buildings while keeping their history visible will be the guiding principle of their work on New River Head.
